info.description:
## Instructions for Day 5: Variables

1.  **Get the challenge:** Fork [the parent collection `Day 05: Variables`](https://www.postman.com/postman/workspace/30-days-of-postman-for-developers/documentation/1559645-7b48e949-713b-4922-bb69-73fb949cd5af) to your own public workspace.
2.  **Read the documentation:** In your fork, select the first folder. Expand the context bar on the right to follow the instructions in the collection documentation.
3.  **Submit your solution:** Select the second folder `Submit your solution` and follow the instructions in the documentation to validate your solution.
    

## Concepts covered

*   [Variable scopes](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/)
*   [Defining variables](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/#defining-variables)
    

## Additional resources

*   [10 tips for working with variables](https://blog.postman.com/10-tips-for-working-with-postman-variables/) blog

item.name: Variables
item.description:
**It's time to work on your next challenge!**

We've already used environment variables in previous challenges. Let's now use the Pok√©mon API to learn more about variables in Postman. This API allows you to retrieve data about different Pok√©mon.

### **Add a request:**

Add a request called **collection variable** to the folder **Variables** with the following details:

- **Method:** GET
    
- **Request URL:** `https://pokeapi.co/api/v2/pokemon/pikachu`
    

### **Add a collection variable:**

- Highlight `https://pokeapi.co/api/v2` in the request URL, right-click and set a new **collection variable** called `pokemonApiBaseUrl` with the value `https://pokeapi.co/api/v2`.
    
- Hover over the new variable to verify that it is set at the correct **collection** scope.
    

**Collection variables** are tightly coupled with a collection and can only be used within that collection. On the other hand, **Environment variables** can be used across multiple collections, similar to how you've stored your Postman API key for different collections.

You can also create and edit collection variables by selecting the collection and navigating to the **Variables** tab. We will also learn how to programmatically set variables in future challenges.

- Replace `https://pokeapi.co/api/v2` in your request URL with `{{pokemonApiBaseUrl}}`, so your updated request URL looks like this:
    

``` bash
{{pokemonApiBaseUrl}}/pokemon/pikachu

 ```

- Hit **Send** to ensure you receive a `200 OK` status code, and save your changes.
    

---

### **Add a global variable:**

- **Duplicate** the request within this folder and rename the second request to **global variable**.
    
- Create a **global variable** using any method you prefer.
    

The global variable should be called `pokemonName` and have the value `pikachu`.

- Replace `pikachu` in the request URL with `{{pokemonName}}`, so your updated request URL looks like this:
    

``` bash
{{pokemonApiBaseUrl}}/pokemon/{{pokemonName}}

 ```

A **global variable** is accessible within the current workspace. You can manually edit global variables in the **Environments** tab on the left sidebar, under **Globals**.

- Update `pokemonName` to another Pok√©mon of your choosing, like `charmander`, and send the request to confirm you receive the corresponding Pok√©mon data.
    

### **Variable Scopes & Good Practices**

Postman provides different **variable scopes** to suit different use cases. Learn more about **variable scopes** and when to choose each.

As you've learned from previous challenges, **initial values** may be accessible to others in a **Team** or **Public workspace**, while **current values** are local and not shared. Since we are working in a **public workspace**, it‚Äôs important to only add sensitive data to **CURRENT VALUE**.

In upcoming challenges, we‚Äôll explore how to **set variables programmatically in scripts**, work with **data variables**, and use **dynamic variables**.

---

Once you complete these steps, move on to the next folder in this collection to submit your solution. Follow the instructions in the request documentation.

request.description:
It's time to submit your solution.

1. **Get the collection ID:** Get the collection `ID` in any way that you prefer.
1. **Update the request URL:** Update the `collectionUid` in the request URL with the `ID` you got from the previous step, again using any method you prefer. 
1. **Add your Postman API key**: Add your [Postman API key](https://go.postman.co/settings/me/api-keys) using any method you prefer, so that Postman can authorize your request as shown under the **Headers** tab.
  > ‚ö† **Remember to only use `CURRENT VALUE` for sensitive tokens like your API key**
1. **Validate your solution**: Save your changes in the collection and environment. Hit **Send** and look under the **Tests** tab of the server response at the bottom to review your test results.

If you have any failures, [review the failed test results](https://youtu.be/S3GKLTVRtmE) or ask for support in the [community forum](https://community.postman.com/). When all of your tests pass, you are done with today's challenge. Remember to save your changes as you'll need to pass all the challenges to claim a **30 days of Postman** badge.
